subject: Re: [junit] Re: Will JUnit 'fail()' trip up ALL code coverage tools?
msgSnippet: Hi, Pat: i have some idea. I am not sure it can help you, but you have a try. just do like this. ********************************* boolean gotException=false;
messageBody:
Hi, Pat:

i have some idea. I am not sure it can help you, but you have a try.
just do like this.

*********************************
boolean gotException=false;
try{
dosomework();
}
catch(Exception e)
{
gotException = true;
dosomething();
}
finally
{
if(!gotException)
fail("some hint");//fail if you did not get your expected exception.
}

Xifeng
----- Original Message -----
From: pmcb552000
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, September 27, 2005 11:54 PM
Subject: [junit] Re: Will JUnit 'fail()' trip up ALL code coverage tools?


Thanks Neil,

That's an interesting way to look at it, but doesn't quite capture
what I want (I still want my JUnit tests to be complete and accurate
without relying on Clover to catch all the 'expected exception' cases
(which are quite common in our codebase at least)).

I like David Saff's idea a bit better (emulating JUnit 4 behaviour
with 'assertThrowsException()'), but in fact, I've now found that
Clover does allow you define custom filters (using regular
expressions), so I'm sure I can define a simple filter to prevent
JUnit's 'fail()' calls from being reported as skipped. I think this
is the easiest and most straightforward solution for me at the moment
(assuming I can work out the correct RegEx!).

But given that this must be a common case, I really think this should
be pointed out somewhere in the Clover docs. Anyway, thanks to all
who responded...

Pat.


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Neil Swingler <neil@s...> wrote:
>
> There are other idioms for testing exceptions which will actually be
supported by using clover.
> e.g.
> try
> {
> somethingDangerous();
> }
> catch(Exception exception)
> {
> assertEquals("message", exception.getMessage());
> }
>
> in this case clover will warn you if the test passed but the
exception was never thrown i.e. we don't need the fail any more
because we've got clover
>
> - Neil
